results.title: London's water supply
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Water Board and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Illustrates how the Board supplies some six and a half million people in and around London with water for all their needs - a daily consumption of 380 million gallons. Shows where the water sources are, water treatment, pumping, quality control and distribution, waste detection and administration.

results.title: London's country
results.creator_credit: Harold Lowenstein, Syd Sharples, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Presents a world of wildlife and flowers and scenic beauty - where people can enjoy yachting on the Thames, or archery at Sevenoaks; riding at Knole Park, or morris-dancing at Westerham; walking over the hills near Newlands Corner, or cricket on the green at Cookham; where they can admire historic buildings - Windsor Castle, Canterbury Cathedral, Farnham Keep, the Dickens houses at Rochester, the Roman ruins at Verulamium.

results.title: London
results.creator_credit: Patrick Keiller, Keith Griffiths and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A ‘documentary’ portrait of the capital which can variously be described as an ‘essay’ or a ‘journal’ (an interesting comparison could be made with Jarman’s ‘essay’ - The Last of England). Images of London in 1992 are accompanied by an unnamed fictional narrator, a friend and former lover of Robinson. The latter is attempting to research the city’s artistic past and support alternative paths that the city’s history might have taken. The film is made up of three ‘expeditions’ and other mini-journeys on foot. The paths taken are inspired by literary-historical concerns but contemporary political events intrude. The two reflect on how political decisions might impact upon the city’s future.

results.title: London
results.brief_description: A musical tour of London showing various historical sites and icons to a selection of tunes including “Around the Marble Arch”, “Let’s all go down The Strand”, “Old father Thames”, “London Bridge is falling down” etc.

results.title: Log house = Cabane de rondins
results.creator_credit: Andreas Poulsson, Michael Rubbo, Roman Bittman and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This film is about the building of a traditional log cabin in Quebec. It starts with the tree and finishes with the housewarming. While it is not a realistic housing option for many Canadians, it does provide encouragement for all of us to re-examine the resources around us that we may not be using effectively, if at all. French dialogue only. (Awards: Brussels; New York)

results.title: Log drive
results.creator_credit: Raymond Garceau, David Bairstow and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: In words and music this 1957 film brings to the screen a great seasonal event of the Quebec spruce forest - the log drive. A ballad singer comments musically on this annual spectacle. Water-borne, the vast aggregation of logs moves downstream, spurred by dynamite and sharp-tipped cant hooks, tossed and twirled by the boots of leaping men.

results.title: Locomotion
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Jones, British Transport Films and Geoffrey Jones Films
results.brief_description: Documentary celebrating 100 years of British railway history and the opening of the world’s first steam hauled public railway, the Stockton and Darlington Line. Its first engine became known as “Locomotion”. Uses collections of prints and sketches of people and architectural sights from a variety of museums and archival and picture libraries in the United Kingdom.

results.title: Local newspaper
results.brief_description: The story of a typical local newspaper - an actual one, the Newbury Weekly News - and of the market town community it serves. Mr Hugh Turner, the editor, a familiar figure in the town, directs the paper, as his father did before him, independently of any big financial group and without fear or favour. The weekly newspaper, local in ownership and range of interests, goes out to be read eagerly and talked over throughout the whole community.

results.title: Local 100
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, James Beveridge and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The story of how Local 100, an affiliate of a national union, was formed. The sudden dismissal of an employee makes the others realise their lack of job security, and discussion of this problem leads to the suggestion that they organise a trade union. The film relates the steps that followed - the approach to the national union, the assistance given by an organiser from union headquarters, and the signing up of the workers which resulted in Local 100 being declared the legal bargaining authority. We see, too, how collective bargaining was carried on to obtain a contract providing job security and improved conditions. The democratic procedure followed throughout proves the contention that free trade unionism is one of the strongest pillars of democracy.

results.title: Loaded
results.creator_credit: Helen Bowden, Susan MacKinnon and Film Australia
results.brief_description: There are estimated to be over four million guns in Australia - one for every fourth person. This documentary introduces a group of men who share a passion for guns. They revere their high powered rifles, their antique pistols and their customised hand guns. The guns are as different as their owners but these men have a common belief in their right to own guns.
